required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Administration of Ondansetron With P-glycoprotein Inhibitor Tariquidar in Patients With Neuropathic Pain

brief_summary.textblock:
Prospective, randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled, cross-over proof of concept study.
To determine the pharmacokinetics and tolerability of co-administration of 5-HT3R antagonist ondansetron with a P-glycoprotein inhibitor tariquidar, in patients with neuropathic pain.

detailed_description.textblock:
The investigators hypothesize that co-administration of a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist ondansetron (single 16mg dose) with p-glycoprotein inhibitor tariquidar (single 4mg/kg dose) vs placebo in a cross-over prospective randomized study, will:
1. Be tolerable in patients with neuropathic pain.
2. Increase the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to plasma ratio of ondansetron after intravenous administration, compare to ondansetron alone
3. Result in a greater reduction in pain intensity than with ondansetron alone.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Prospective, randomized, double blind, crossover study

primary_outcome.measure: Concertation-time Profile of Ondansetron in Plasma
primary_outcome.description: Venous blood sampling for plasma concentrations of ondansetron will be obtained: at 0, 15, 30, 60, 90, 120, 180, and 240 minutes from the beginning of ondansetron infusion, and compared between the two sessions (with placebo vs tariquidar)

primary_outcome.measure: Cerebrospinal Fluid to Plasma Concentration Ratio of Ondansetron
primary_outcome.description: Cerebrospinal fluid to plasma concentration ratio of ondansetron, compared between the two sessions, with placebo vs tariquidar

primary_outcome.measure: Cerebrospinal Fluid Penetration of Ondansetron - Area Under the Curve (AUC)
primary_outcome.description: Cerebrospinal fluid penetration of intravenous ondansetron will be determined as AUCCSF0-∞ of ondansetron, and compared between the two sessions, with placebo vs tariquidar

secondary_outcome.description: Change in spontaneous pain intensity (measured on 0-10 numerical rating scale; 0=no pain, 10=worst imaginable pain) from baseline to 60-120 minutes after ondansetron IV infusion, compared between two sessions with and without tariquidar.

The difference between self-report intensity of pain (0-100 scale) as a response to a standard contact heat stimulus, compared to the same experiment performed with ice-water conditioning applied to the contralateral extremity. A larger negative value of CPM represents more efficient pain modulation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between CPM Magnitude (ΔCPM) and Change in Pain Intensity
secondary_outcome.description: The association between baseline Conditioned Pain Modulation (CPM) magnitude (ΔCPM) and the % pain reduction from baseline will be determined by bivariate regression.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Neuropathic Pain Symptom Score
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in Neuropathic Pain Symptom Inventory (NPSI) total score and sub-scores (burning pain, paroxysmal pain, paresthesia/dysesthesia score) will be compared between treatment sessions. Each subscore is scored on a 0-10 scale: 0=no symptom, 10=worst imaginable symptom

intervention.description: In randomized order, each participant will receive two IV infusions of ondansetron, 3 weeks apart; one with placebo (D5W), and one with tariquidar (4mg/kg dose in D5W) administered IV over 60 minutes. Ondansetron will be diluted in 100mL 0.9% normal saline, and tariquidar will be diluted in 500mL D5W.

In randomized order, each participant will receive two IV infusions of ondansetron, 3 weeks apart; one with placebo (D5W), and one with tariquidar (4mg/kg dose in D5W) administered IV over 60 minutes. Ondansetron will be diluted in 100mL 0.9% normal saline, and tariquidar will be diluted in 500mL D5W.

facility.name: Washington University School of Medicine/Barnes-Jewish Hospital

reference.citation: Finnerup NB, Haroutounian S, Kamerman P, Baron R, Bennett DLH, Bouhassira D, Cruccu G, Freeman R, Hansson P, Nurmikko T, Raja SN, Rice ASC, Serra J, Smith BH, Treede RD, Jensen TS. Neuropathic pain: an updated grading system for research and clinical practice. Pain. 2016 Aug;157(8):1599-1606. doi: 10.1097/j.pain.0000000000000492. Review.

Yawn BP, Wollan PC, Weingarten TN, Watson JC, Hooten WM, Melton LJ 3rd. The prevalence of neuropathic pain: clinical evaluation compared with screening tools in a community population. Pain Med. 2009 Apr;10(3):586-93. doi: 10.1111/j.1526-4637.2009.00588.x. Epub 2009 Mar 17. Erratum in: Pain Med. 2011 Aug;12(8):1294.
Smith BH, Torrance N. Epidemiology of neuropathic pain and its impact on quality of life. Curr Pain Headache Rep. 2012 Jun;16(3):191-8. doi: 10.1007/s11916-012-0256-0. Review.
